trans-unit.source: Working With Files Folders and Registry Keys
trans-unit.target: Working With Files Folders and Registry Keys

trans-unit.source: powershell,cmdlet
trans-unit.target: powershell,cmdlet

trans-unit.source: Working With Files, Folders and Registry Keys
trans-unit.target: Working With Files, Folders and Registry Keys

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell uses the noun **Item** to refer to items found on a Windows PowerShell drive.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell uses the noun **Item** to refer to items found on a Windows PowerShell drive.

trans-unit.source: When dealing with the Windows PowerShell FileSystem provider, an **Item** might be a file, a folder, or the Windows PowerShell drive.
trans-unit.target: When dealing with the Windows PowerShell FileSystem provider, an **Item** might be a file, a folder, or the Windows PowerShell drive.

trans-unit.source: Listing and working with these items is a critical basic task in most administrative settings, so we want to discuss these tasks in detail.
trans-unit.target: Listing and working with these items is a critical basic task in most administrative settings, so we want to discuss these tasks in detail.

trans-unit.source: Enumerating Files, Folders, and Registry Keys (Get-ChildItem)
trans-unit.target: Enumerating Files, Folders, and Registry Keys (Get-ChildItem)

trans-unit.source: Since getting a collection of items from a particular location is such a common task, the **Get-ChildItem** cmdlet is designed specifically to return all items found within a container such as a folder.
trans-unit.target: Since getting a collection of items from a particular location is such a common task, the **Get-ChildItem** cmdlet is designed specifically to return all items found within a container such as a folder.

trans-unit.source: If you want to return all files and folders that are contained directly within the folder C:\\Windows, type:
trans-unit.target: If you want to return all files and folders that are contained directly within the folder C:\\Windows, type:

trans-unit.source: The listing looks similar to what you would see when you enter the **dir** command in **Cmd.exe**, or the **ls** command in a UNIX command shell.
trans-unit.target: The listing looks similar to what you would see when you enter the **dir** command in **Cmd.exe**, or the **ls** command in a UNIX command shell.

trans-unit.source: You can perform very complex listings by using parameters of the **Get-ChildItem** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can perform very complex listings by using parameters of the **Get-ChildItem** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: We will look at a few scenarios next.
trans-unit.target: We will look at a few scenarios next.

trans-unit.source: You can see the syntax the **Get-ChildItem** cmdlet by typing:
trans-unit.target: You can see the syntax the **Get-ChildItem** cmdlet by typing:

trans-unit.source: These parameters can be mixed and matched to get highly customized output.
trans-unit.target: These parameters can be mixed and matched to get highly customized output.

trans-unit.source: Listing all Contained Items (-Recurse)
trans-unit.target: Listing all Contained Items (-Recurse)

trans-unit.source: To see both the items inside a Windows folder and any items that are contained within the subfolders, use the **Recurse** parameter of **Get-ChildItem**.
trans-unit.target: To see both the items inside a Windows folder and any items that are contained within the subfolders, use the **Recurse** parameter of **Get-ChildItem**.

trans-unit.source: The listing displays everything within the Windows folder and the items in its subfolders.
trans-unit.target: The listing displays everything within the Windows folder and the items in its subfolders.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Filtering Items by Name (-Name)
trans-unit.target: Filtering Items by Name (-Name)

trans-unit.source: To display only the names of items, use the **Name** parameter of **Get-Childitem**:
trans-unit.target: To display only the names of items, use the **Name** parameter of **Get-Childitem**:

trans-unit.source: Forcibly Listing Hidden Items (-Force)
trans-unit.target: Forcibly Listing Hidden Items (-Force)

trans-unit.source: Items that are normally invisible in File Explorer or Cmd.exe are not displayed in the output of a **Get-ChildItem** command.
trans-unit.target: Items that are normally invisible in File Explorer or Cmd.exe are not displayed in the output of a **Get-ChildItem** command.

trans-unit.source: To display hidden items, use the **Force** parameter of **Get-ChildItem**.
trans-unit.target: To display hidden items, use the **Force** parameter of **Get-ChildItem**.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: This parameter is named Force because you can forcibly override the normal behavior of the **Get-ChildItem** command.
trans-unit.target: This parameter is named Force because you can forcibly override the normal behavior of the **Get-ChildItem** command.

trans-unit.source: Force is a widely used parameter that forces an action that a cmdlet would not normally perform, although it will not perform any action that compromises the security of the system.
trans-unit.target: Force is a widely used parameter that forces an action that a cmdlet would not normally perform, although it will not perform any action that compromises the security of the system.

trans-unit.source: Matching Item Names with Wildcards
trans-unit.target: Matching Item Names with Wildcards

trans-unit.source: **The Get-ChildItem** command accepts wildcards in the path of the items to list.
trans-unit.target: **The Get-ChildItem** command accepts wildcards in the path of the items to list.

trans-unit.source: Because wildcard matching is handled by the Windows PowerShell engine, all cmdlets that accepts wildcards use the same notation and have the same matching behavior.
trans-unit.target: Because wildcard matching is handled by the Windows PowerShell engine, all cmdlets that accepts wildcards use the same notation and have the same matching behavior.

trans-unit.source: The Windows PowerShell wildcard notation includes:
trans-unit.target: The Windows PowerShell wildcard notation includes:

trans-unit.source: Asterisk (\*)matches zero or more occurrences of any character.
trans-unit.target: Asterisk (\*)matches zero or more occurrences of any character.

trans-unit.source: Question mark (?) matches exactly one character.
trans-unit.target: Question mark (?) matches exactly one character.

trans-unit.source: Left bracket (\[) character and right bracket (]) character surround a set of characters to be matched.
trans-unit.target: Left bracket (\[) character and right bracket (]) character surround a set of characters to be matched.

trans-unit.source: Here are some examples of how wildcard specification works.
trans-unit.target: Here are some examples of how wildcard specification works.

trans-unit.source: To find all files in the Windows directory with the suffix **.log** and exactly five characters in the base name, enter the following command:
trans-unit.target: To find all files in the Windows directory with the suffix **.log** and exactly five characters in the base name, enter the following command:

trans-unit.source: To find all files that begin with the letter **x** in the Windows directory, type:
trans-unit.target: To find all files that begin with the letter **x** in the Windows directory, type:

trans-unit.source: To find all files whose names begin with **x** or **z**, type:
trans-unit.target: To find all files whose names begin with **x** or **z**, type:

trans-unit.source: Excluding Items (-Exclude)
trans-unit.target: Excluding Items (-Exclude)

trans-unit.source: You can exclude specific items by using the **Exclude** parameter of Get-ChildItem.
trans-unit.target: You can exclude specific items by using the **Exclude** parameter of Get-ChildItem.

trans-unit.source: This lets you perform complex filtering in a single statement.
trans-unit.target: This lets you perform complex filtering in a single statement.

trans-unit.source: For example, suppose you are trying to find the Windows Time Service DLL in the System32 folder, and all you can remember about the DLL name is that it begins with "W" and has "32" in it.
trans-unit.target: For example, suppose you are trying to find the Windows Time Service DLL in the System32 folder, and all you can remember about the DLL name is that it begins with "W" and has "32" in it.

trans-unit.source: An expression like **w\*32\*.dll** will find all DLLs that satisfy the conditions, but it may also return the Windows 95 and 16-bit Windows compatibility DLLs that include "95" or "16" in their names.
trans-unit.target: An expression like **w\*32\*.dll** will find all DLLs that satisfy the conditions, but it may also return the Windows 95 and 16-bit Windows compatibility DLLs that include "95" or "16" in their names.

trans-unit.source: You can omit files that have any of these numbers in their names by using the **Exclude** parameter with the pattern **\*\[9516]\***:
trans-unit.target: You can omit files that have any of these numbers in their names by using the **Exclude** parameter with the pattern **\*\[9516]\***:

trans-unit.source: PS> Get-ChildItem -Path C:\WINDOWS\System32\w*32*.dll -Exclude *[9516]* Directory: Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\FileSystem::C:\WINDOWS\System32 Mode LastWriteTime Length Name ---- ------------- ------ ---- -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 174592 w32time.dll -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 22016 w32topl.dll -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 101888 win32spl.dll -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 172032 wldap32.dll -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 264192 wow32.dll -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 82944 ws2_32.dll -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 42496 wsnmp32.dll -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 22528 wsock32.dll -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 18432 wtsapi32.dll
trans-unit.target: PS> Get-ChildItem -Path C:\WINDOWS\System32\w*32*.dll -Exclude *[9516]* Directory: Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\FileSystem::C:\WINDOWS\System32 Mode LastWriteTime Length Name ---- ------------- ------ ---- -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 174592 w32time.dll -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 22016 w32topl.dll -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 101888 win32spl.dll -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 172032 wldap32.dll -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 264192 wow32.dll -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 82944 ws2_32.dll -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 42496 wsnmp32.dll -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 22528 wsock32.dll -a--- 2004-08-04 8:00 AM 18432 wtsapi32.dll

trans-unit.source: Mixing Get-ChildItem Parameters
trans-unit.target: Mixing Get-ChildItem Parameters

trans-unit.source: You can use several of the parameters of the **Get-ChildItem** cmdlet in the same command.
trans-unit.target: You can use several of the parameters of the **Get-ChildItem** cmdlet in the same command.

trans-unit.source: Before you mix parameters, be sure that you understand wildcard matching.
trans-unit.target: Before you mix parameters, be sure that you understand wildcard matching.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following command returns no results:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following command returns no results:

trans-unit.source: There are no results, even though there are two DLLs that begin with the letter "z" in the Windows folder.
trans-unit.target: There are no results, even though there are two DLLs that begin with the letter "z" in the Windows folder.

trans-unit.source: No results were returned because we specified the wildcard as part of the path.
trans-unit.target: No results were returned because we specified the wildcard as part of the path.

trans-unit.source: Even though the command was recursive, the **Get-ChildItem** cmdlet restricted the items to those that are in the Windows folder with names ending with ".dll".
trans-unit.target: Even though the command was recursive, the **Get-ChildItem** cmdlet restricted the items to those that are in the Windows folder with names ending with ".dll".

trans-unit.source: To specify a recursive search for files whose names match a special pattern, use the **-Include** parameter.
trans-unit.target: To specify a recursive search for files whose names match a special pattern, use the **-Include** parameter.
